37.29.text:
Our journey begins at the island town of Lindau
on Lake Constance.

42.01.text:
We then head west past a series of dramatic
castles before arriving at the spa town of

48.24.text:
From there it is east past the city of Ulm
and then southwards to Fusen and on into the

55.76.text: Bavarian Alps and a series of fantasy castles.

59.73.text:
At Oberammergau we head east to Lake Chiemsee
before heading further east into the Alps

67.71.text:
and on to Berchtesgaden and a dramatic house
on top of a mountain.

76.30.text:
Running roughly along the middle of Lake Constance
is the border between Germany, Switzerland

82.38.text:
In Germany the lake is called the Bodensee
and on this island is the ancient Bavarian

89.89.text:
It was only joined to the mainland in 1853
when the causeway was built, which enabled

94.92.text: trains and carriages to get to the island.

97.79.text:
This was followed by a new harbour and Bavaria's
only lighthouse.

103.52.text:
In its history the town has belonged to both
Austria and France, and it was only in 1955

109.76.text:
that it was finally returned to Germany by
the French.

114.28.text:
Every year, since 1951, there is a Nobel Laureate
scientific meeting in Landau where prize winners

121.69.text:
interact with young researchers from all over
the world.

128.09.text:
It was only in the middle of the 19th century
that Germany, as we know it today, came into

132.48.text: being under the guiding hand of Otto Von Bismark.

136.70.text:
He unified a series of independent federal
states into one country.

142.02.text:
This was also a period which saw German Romanticism
become a dominant movement and one of its

147.68.text:
most visual symbols are all the castles, rebuilt
in a romantic medieval style.

156.23.text:
This is Sigmaringen Castle, once home to the
princes of Hohenzollern-Sigmaringen.

160.51.text:
It has its roots back in the 11th century
though what we see today dates from the 19th

168.12.text:
It was built to impress and became a meeting
point for the rich and powerful nobility of

173.73.text:
The deep sided valleys with rocky crags gave
castle builders an excellent vantage point

182.55.text:
to site a fortress, and later in the 19th
century rebuild them in a romantic style that

195.99.text: Perched on this crag is Werenwag Castle.

200.72.text:
There has been a castle on this site since
the 12th century, but what we see today dates

206.44.text:
from the 1830's when the Princes of Furstenberg
inherited Werenwag and began remodelling it

216.50.text:
One can only imagine how hard it must have
been for the men who had to build it on this

232.25.text:
Since then the castle has suffered a fire
in the 1890's and even an earthquake in 1911

237.98.text:
when a staircase tower and some of the battlements
suffered cracks and falling masonry.

248.46.text:
On the other side of the valley is Wildenstein
Castle.

251.15.text:
Begun in the 12th century what we see today
still includes some parts of the original.

257.70.text:
A narrow bridge joins the stables and ancillary
buildings to the main castle on its rocky

270.15.text:
Castles come in all sorts of styles and sizes
in this part of Germany and many are perched

275.34.text: on rocky outcrops with wonderful views.

279.40.text:
However, this small castle cannot compare
to another 20 miles to the north, which is

286.96.text:
one of the great castles of Europe, and one
that can be seen from miles around.

296.47.text:
Sitting on top of this near 3,000ft mountain
is Hohenzollern castle.

301.34.text:
It was built by Frederick William IV, king
of Prussia starting in 1850, and it took seventeen

311.42.text:
This is another good example of a German romantic
movement castle, built on an enormous scale.

318.53.text:
The style incorporates the idealised vision
of what a medieval knight's castle should

322.77.text:
look like, though it is doubtful it ever really
looked like this fairy-tale version.

331.35.text:
It was also designed to impress and enhance
the reputation of the Prussian Royal Family,

336.59.text:
who could trace their roots back to the first
castle on the site in the 11th century.

342.99.text:
In 1423 Hohenzollern was besieged for a year
and totally destroyed.

348.18.text: Only written records tell of its existence.

352.03.text:
Thirty years later it was rebuilt and then
over the next three centuries was occupied

357.34.text:
by various different countries including the
Austrians and later the French.

363.09.text:
By the end of the 18th century the castle
was falling into ruins.

366.99.text:
Only the chapel of St Michael remained usable
and was incorporated into the third incarnation

374.52.text:
After the castle was rebuilt it was not regularly
occupied but rather used as a show place.

381.15.text:
It is still privately owned by two lines of
the Hohenzollern family.

387.46.text:
Today the castle has over 300,000 visitors
a year, making it one of the most popular

397.30.text:
On a smaller scale but no less impressive
is Lichtenstein Castle above the town of Honau.

421.03.text:
This romantic neo-gothic castle was built
in the 1840's for Duke Wilhelm of Urach, count

428.48.text:
The design was inspired by a popular historical
novel, Lichtenstein, published in 1826.

437.61.text:
Just as at Hohenzollern this is the third
castle on the site with the first two destroyed

442.80.text:
in fairly quick succession during the 14th
century.

446.56.text:
After that it fell into disrepair until it
came into the hands of Duke Wilhelm.

454.10.text:
Some of the lower rooms are carved out of
the rock which supports the building.

459.09.text:
The tall tower was added fifty years later
at the end of the 19th century.

466.54.text:
And the fairy-tale castle still belongs to
the Dukes of Urach and is a very popular place

478.17.text:
Twelve miles away is the town of Tubingen,
one of the five classical university towns

483.49.text:
in Germany, the other four being Marburg,
Gottingen, Freiburg and Heidelberg.

490.59.text:
The old castle is now part of the University
and the 25,000 students account for nearly

496.14.text: a third of the town's population.

499.58.text:
Amongst the eminent students who no doubt
walked through these ancient streets was the

503.78.text:
astronomer Johannes Kepler at the end of the
16th century, and in the 20th century, Joseph

516.34.text:
To the west and on the edge of the Black Forest
is the spa town of Baden Baden.

522.24.text:
The German word Baden translates as 'to bath
or to bathe'.

527.10.text:
In early days the town was simply known as
Baden, and the double name only officially

532.52.text:
came into use in 1931 and was shortened from
Baden in Baden, as the town is in the state

542.50.text:
It was way back in the Roman times that the
healing power of water was first recognised.

547.72.text:
It is thought that the emperor Hadrian founded
the town and certainly Emperor Caracalla came

553.46.text: here to ease his arthritic aches.

556.76.text:
After the collapse of the Roman empire the
town declined and fell into partial ruin for

562.89.text:
It was only at the end of the 18th century
that Baden was rediscovered as a spa town.

569.17.text:
And in the early 19th century the resort attracted
the rich and famous including the composers

574.68.text:
Berlioz and Brahms and the writer Dostoyevsky,
who wrote 'The Gambler' whilst gambling himself

586.64.text:
European royalty came to stay in the luxury
hotels, including Queen Victoria, Napoleon

591.74.text: III and the German Emperor Wilhelm I.

598.62.text:
High on a hill overlooking Bad Urach is the
old castle of Hohenurach, which was used as

604.65.text: a prison during the middle ages.

606.95.text:
Over the centuries it was feared and hated
by the local people, so that when the prison

613.47.text:
shut down in the 18th century they climbed
the hill and destroyed it.

621.03.text:
The old centre of Bad Urach is full of half-timbered
houses.

632.77.text:
The same cannot be said of the city of Ulm,
thirty miles to the east.

637.15.text:
A devastating air raid in 1944 destroyed much
of the city, but the glorious church was left

647.18.text:
Even the houses around the square in front
of the church, where the market is, were wrecked.

652.98.text:
The church is large enough to be a cathedral,
but as Ulm is not a seat of a bishop it is

660.67.text:
However, it is the tallest church in the world
at just under 170 metres.

668.37.text:
From the top it is possible to look south
on a clear day and see the Alps over seventy

688.07.text:
Building began in the mid14th century, and
was held up several times with work halted

696.12.text:
It was only in 1813 that work began again
and the church was finally completed in 1890.

715.83.text:
Ten miles to the east is Roggenberg Abbey,
which was founded back in the 10th century,

720.81.text:
though what we see today dates from the mid18th
century.

726.22.text:
In 1802 the monastery was closed down during
a period of secularisation and the abbot stripped

735.24.text:
In 1986 in a move that comes full circle the
abbey buildings and church have been returned

742.70.text:
to a new set of monks who are re-establishing
the abbey as a thriving community after a

758.65.text:
Our journey now heads south through the Bavarian
landscape towards the foothills of the Alps,

764.24.text:
the great mountain range that acts as the
border with Austria and Switzerland.

768.44.text:
And lying close to the border on the north
side of the River Lech is the old town of

778.14.text:
It was the Romans who founded the town here
as it was on a main road through the mountains

782.73.text:
to Italy, and they needed a base for soldiers
in order to guard the route.

788.62.text:
The town's landmark is the castle, which overlooks
the town and is one of the area's best preserved

797.98.text:
The town itself is full of medieval houses
and the centre remains remarkably untouched.

807.98.text:
Fussen has become a popular place to stay
when exploring the beautiful mountain landscape,

813.23.text: as well as two remarkable castles.

821.25.text:
The first is Hohenschwangau built on the remains
of an earlier castle in 1833 by King Maximillian

828.28.text: II of Bavaria and his wife Marie of Prussian.

833.16.text:
The queen particularly enjoyed walking in
the mountains, and often took her two sons

840.68.text:
When Ludwig inherited the throne in 1864 he
began planning and building one of the most

847.98.text:
remarkable fantasy castles in the world less
than a mile away from his childhood home on

854.17.text: the site of another old castle.

872.09.text:
This is Neuschwanstein Castle designed as
a personal refuge for King Ludwig, who gradually

882.16.text:
He had become obsessed with Richard Wagner's
operas, and in a way the castle was to be

887.39.text:
an interpretation of his most famous works
-- Tannhauser and Lohengrin.

892.94.text:
Wagner's music made a lasting impression on
the young king and this is part of a letter

899.10.text:
he wrote to Wagner in 1868 about his new picturesque
castle.

904.52.text:
'It is my intention to rebuild the old castle
ruin of Hohenschwangau near the Pollat Gorge

911.02.text:
in the authentic style of the old German knight's
castle, and I must confess to you that I am

916.97.text:
looking forward very much to living there
one day.

920.55.text:
You know the revered guest I would like to
accommodate there; the location is one of

926.81.text:
the most beautiful to be found, holy and unapproachable,
a worthy temple for the divine friend who

933.52.text:
has brought salvation and true blessings to
the world.'

940.85.text:
The cost of the castle was immense and would
run to over a hundred million pounds today.

945.72.text:
At various times over 300 workmen would be
employed and often working at night by the

954.64.text:
All the funding came from the king's purse
and the money he borrowed.

960.81.text:
Costs inevitably escalated and by the end
the castle had cost twice the original budget.

967.12.text:
One of the reasons for siting the castle here
may well have been the view he got from the

971.47.text: bridge his mother had built to span the gorge.

974.75.text:
She loved walking in this landscape, and it
must have had a powerful effect on young Ludwig.

980.77.text:
Sadly he only spent a 172 days in his fantasy
castle.

986.70.text:
Because Ludwig was finally declared mentally
unstable and died aged only 41 in 1886.

994.90.text:
He was later to be known, perhaps unkindly,
as Mad King Ludwig'.

1000.11.text:
But he left behind one of the most remarkable
fairy-tale castles ever built, and the inspiration

1007.01.text: for Sleeping Beauty's castle in Disneyland.

1014.69.text:
As a child Ludwig had enjoyed hunting trips
with his father and in a valley not far from

1024.95.text:
his home he inherited his father's hunting
lodge.

1032.95.text:
With his obsession for grandiose building
projects he eventually tore it down and built

1038.00.text:
the Linderhof Palace, but this time in a more
classical French style, which looked back

1043.86.text: to his idol Louis XIV, the Sun King of France.

1049.39.text:
He intended Linderhof, named after the surrounding
linden trees, to be like the Royal Palace

1054.50.text:
of Versailles but this was never realised,
as he later obtained an island on a large

1059.95.text:
lake where his grand plan to match the size
of Versailles could be carried out.

1065.04.text: Later on in our journey we will see the result.

1069.48.text:
Linderhof may be the smallest of Ludwig's
palaces but it is still an impressive site.

1075.49.text:
The formal gardens surrounding the house certainly
have the feel of the French style of the time.

1082.57.text:
To the north the sloping ground enabled a
cascade to be built, where the flowing water

1087.26.text:
could fall over thirty marble steps and then
drop into the Neptune fountain at the bottom.

1093.70.text: At the top is the music pavilion

1096.67.text:
On the west and east sides are formal colourful
parterres, with statues, fountains and covered

1106.17.text:
On the south side a golden fountain could
rise up around seventy feet and stands at

1111.62.text:
the foot of a three stepped terraced garden
leading up to a golden topped temple.

1117.25.text:
In the park, inspired by the English landscape
movement, he had garden buildings put up including

1124.18.text: a Moorish Kiosk, which he bought in 1876.

1129.69.text:
Needless to say his extravagance knew no bounds
and eventually led to his downfall.

1142.71.text:
Right at the other end of the valley is one
of the most important monasteries in the Alpine

1146.99.text:
region, and built on the primary trade route
between northern Italy and the city of Augsburg

1157.78.text:
The Benedictine abbey was first founded back
in the 14th century, but what we see today

1162.45.text:
is from the mid -18th century and built in
the Baroque style.

1167.95.text:
This followed a disastrous fire in 1744 when
the abbey church and many of the other buildings

1176.78.text:
This was the beginning of the golden age of
Ettal and in this period the 'Knights' Academy'

1182.14.text:
was established, which developed into a highly
successful school.

1185.87.text:
But all this came to an end with the secularisation
of church property in 1803.

1194.69.text:
And it was not until 1898 that the buildings
were bought back by a wealthy Catholic supporter

1200.94.text:
and given to a group of Benedictine monks
from a nearby monastery.

1206.59.text:
A mile away to the north is Oberammargau,
a town which is known the world over for its

1219.19.text:
It began because of a vow the local inhabitants
made that if God spared them from the plague

1225.12.text: they would stage the Passion every ten years.

1228.19.text:
They were spared and since then the play is
performed in the years ending in '0'.

1234.40.text:
The 2010 play involved around 2,000 people,
and lasted for seven hours with performances

1246.74.text:
Sixty miles to the east on the edge of the
Bavarian Alps is Chiemsee, a freshwater lake.

1254.86.text:
It is sometimes referred to as the Bavarian
Sea, and is a very popular place for sailing

1260.15.text: and all the other water sports.

1262.10.text:
Those looking for a gentler means of travel
might take a trip on the old paddle steamers,

1268.63.text:
which offer a more sedate way of seeing the
lake.

1275.41.text:
The lake has a number of islands and the second
largest is Frauenchiemsee.

1281.20.text:
The paddle steamers drop off both visitors,
as well as those residents who do not have

1285.80.text: their own boats to get to and from the island.

1290.17.text:
The island itself is car free and has a local
population of around 300 people.

1296.96.text:
Visitors in their thousands come to see the
Benedictine Convent, which was founded back

1303.10.text:
To help raise funds for the convent the nuns
make a local drink called Cloister Liquor,

1310.56.text: as well as an excellent marzipan.

1316.66.text:
The largest island on the lake is Herrenchiemsee
and hidden in the woods is King Ludwig's unfinished

1323.69.text: tribute to the palace of Versailles in France.

1344.11.text:
Unfortunately Ludwig only spent a few days
here a year before he died.

1348.19.text:
However the cost of what he did build probably
equates to about 70 million pounds today.

1355.81.text:
Only the central section was constructed,
as all building was halted a year after Ludwig's

1364.11.text:
The section of garden which was completed
copies the style of Versailles with fountains

1369.24.text:
and parterres, as well as a long central allee,
or avenue, which runs right across the island

1377.63.text:
And as the palace is on an island and only
accessible by a small ferry it has remained

1382.71.text:
in the shadow of Ludwig's best known castle
-- Neuschwanstein.

1386.97.text:
But this island palace is well worth the trip
for anyone interested in the architecture

1402.04.text:
For our last destination we head east into
the Bavarian Alps and Berchtesgaden, a place

1408.54.text:
forever associated with the Nazi leader, Adolf
Hitler.

1412.07.text:
His house near Berchtesgaden has been destroyed,
but one mountain top house given to him as

1416.84.text: a present does survive -- the Eagles Nest.

1421.20.text:
It survives because it was given to him as
a present in 1939, but he rarely visited it

1427.21.text:
and this lack of a close association saved
it from demolition after the war.

1432.82.text:
It was built by Martin Bormann on top of 6,000ft
ridge, and reached by a four mile private

1438.95.text:
road carved into the mountainside, which goes
through five tunnels.

1445.46.text:
The cost today of just the road has been estimated
at over 100 million pounds.

1453.14.text:
On the other side of the mountain the road
ends at a car park below the house, where

1461.37.text:
From here a tunnel leads into the mountain
where a 407ft lift carries visitors up to

1469.64.text:
As we climb up to take a look we discover
we are not the only aircraft in the area and

1474.51.text:
decide to give a wide berth to the powered
hang-glider.

1479.33.text:
The Eagle's Nest is now a small restaurant
and bar where visitors can marvel at the view,

1485.25.text:
though as the clouds thicken it is difficult
to see anything.

1491.64.text:
This weather also makes flying dangerous,
and we need to descend into clearer air, so

1495.39.text: this is a good time to end this journey.
